content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) has asylum information in English, German, Russian, and Turkish. 

The Ministry of the Interior has further information in English.

BAMF works on asylum procedures with the local immigration offices, the Federal Office of Administration, the Federal Police, federal and regional security authorities, and the UNHCR.

  • To apply for asylum in Germany, you must file an application for asylum with a branch office of BAMF. 
  • While your asylum application is pending you will get a residence permit, which allows you to stay in Germany during your asylum procedure. This entitles you to work, but, NOT during the first three months of your stay in Germany.
  • Persons granted asylum status and those granted refugee status receive a temporary residence permit and are entitled to social welfare, child benefits, child-raising benefits, integration allowances, and language courses, as well as other forms of integration assistance.
  • As a rule, asylum seekers whose applications have been rejected are required to leave the country.

The German Bar Association answers some common questions, such as:

  • how to prepare for your interview
  • what can you do if the BAMF rejects your application for asylum
  • if you are allowed to work
  • if you are allowed to freely choose your place of residence, and
  • how much money you will receive for living expenses.

Additional Information:

  • Information in different languages about the Asylum Interview Process (in Arabic and Persian)
  • General information for women asylum seekers.

content.title: FAMILY REUNIFICATION
content.section:
• ​The German Red Cross helps people look for family members in Germany.
  • The German Red Cross, together with the ICRC and National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies abroad, helps people in Germany look for family members in another country.
  • The German Red Cross helps people in Germany restore and maintain contact with family members in another country through Red Cross messages.
  • The German Red Cross offers guidance and legal support in family reunification matters. However, the legal decision for any reunification is taken by government authorities.
  • ​The German Red Cross can try to find information for people who are worried about the health and well-being of a close family member with whom they have suddenly lost contact. In particular, they try to find information about elderly or sick people.​
  • Their services are free of charge, and they will treat your information confidentially.

content.title: GENDER-BASED VIOLENCE SUPPORT AND ANTI-TRAFFICKING
content.section:
• KOK e.V. is the "German Network and Coordination Office Against Trafficking In Human Beings", a non-governmental organisation that fights trafficking of women and furthering immigrants’ rights. Here is a searchable list of NGOs that provide support.
  • Many of these organizations work specifically with women because of their origins and their financing, although many of them do support men as well, or at least can recommend an adequate counselling centre.
  • The majority of KOK e.V. members work on human trafficking regarding sexual and labor exploitation.
  • The counselling is always voluntary and can be offered in the client’s native language. The counsellors work with professional discretion and treat all information with great responsibility.
  • If you are looking for an organisation close to you, you can find it on their map of Germany.

content.title: COUNSELING
content.section:
• The Nationwide Association of Psychosocial Centers for Refugees and Victims of Torture eV (BAFF) has links to 30 psycho-social treatment centers and intiatives for medical and psychological care of victims of trauma, torture, and other serious human rights violations. Here is a listing of member centers and supporting members (in English). 


Berlin

  • Contact and Consultation Center for Refugees and Migrants in Berlin-Kreuzberg (Kontakt- und Beratungsstelle für Flüchtlinge und Migrant_innen e.V. – KuB) is a registered non-profit association, whose purpose it is to provide support and consultation services for refugees and migrants.
  • XENION is a Berlin-based centre for the psychotherapeutic counselling and treatment of traumatised refugees and survivors of torture and other serious human rights abuses. They offer support as asylum seekers make their application for asylum.
  • ARIBA offers counseling for those who have suffered from right-wing or racist/ anti-immigrant attacks in Berlin.
  • MeG betreutes Wohnen offers mental health services and housing for mentally ill refugees in Berlin.

content.title: MEDICAL ASSISTANCE
content.section:
As a refugee you have a right to medical treatment even if you do not have a residence title. This link provides important information on, and addresses for, the German healthcare system (in Arabic, Farsi, and English).

  • In an emergency, you can always dial the German emergency telephone number 112 or go to the emergency room of a hospital.
  • People without papers, for example refugees without residence status, can get free help in so-called “Medibüros” in many German cities. An overview can be found here.

Click here for additional contacts for medical care in Germany (listed in alphabetical order of the city).

  • When you’re going to the doctor, you will find translations for basic terms in a Google-Sheet made by Refugee Phrasebook. Available languages include: Albanian, Arabic, Dari, Farsi, Pashto, Sorani, Kurmanji.
  • Translations of anamnesis- and examination-transcripts in many languages can be found on tipcdoc.de. They created a health-brochure (pdf) as well, which can be printed and carried to the doctor for an easier conversation. It includes translations in Albanian, Arabic, Dari, Farsi, Urdu and Tigrinya.
  • A descriptive questionnaire German/ Arabic (pdf) has been created by “Pharmazeutische Zeitung”.
  • For victims of torture and traumatized refugees there are psycho-social centres, which help in a professional way. There are thirty of these centres all across Germany.

German pharmacies are common, even in smaller towns, and are easy to find. Just look for a red stylized "A" or the word "Apotheke" (www.apotheken.de). Pharmacies are usually open from 08:00-18:00 Monday -Friday, and are generally closed evenings, Saturday afternoons, Sundays, and holidays. Each of them has a list on the door, though, of pharmacies in the area that remain open to handle emergencies.

content.title: EDUCATION
content.section:
• After being entitled to asylum, an integration course is obligatory in Germany. Through a postcode-search you can find an organizer nearby here (in English or German). 
  • In the meantime, you can learn a little of the German language through this tool.
  • For Arabic-speaking refugees, this language learning app is also for free (iOS).

CHILDREN'S EDUCATION

  • All children who reside in Germany have the right and obligation to attend school, regardless of their status. From ages three to six, children may attend kindergarten. From six to sixteen years of age, children must attend school.
  • Please note that Germany is a federal government and that there are important distinctions in terms of laws and practices in the different states.
  • It might be important to know, for instance, if in the state where you reside, education is compulsory for children aged 16 or older.
  • To find the Ministry of Education in the state where you live, click here.

For more information on education for your children, go to:

  • Asylum in Europe's education page.
  • or How To Germany's explanation of the German school system.

content.title: INTEGRATION ASSISTANCE
content.section:
• Asylum applicants and other groups of individuals with good prospects to remain may be admitted to attend an integration course, assuming places are available on the courses.
  • Foreigners who hold temporary permission to stay and whose residence is anticipated to be lawful and permanent, foreigners who hold a temporary suspension of deportation, and foreigners who hold a residence permit may file an application to BAMF headquarters for admittance to an integration course.
  • You can do so by completing an application form. 
  • Once you have received your certificate of eligibility for the integration course (Berechtigungsschein) from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, you can choose an integration course provider. 
  • These courses are free. 
  • For more information (in English or German), click here. 

In the meantime, these two guides help with German customs and practices:

  • Refugee Guide (available in Arabic, Dari, Pashto, Urdu, English and a number of other languages)
  • ARD’s Guide for Refugees

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: BASIC INFORMATION
content.section:
You are in Italy. 

 

Vital Arrival Information: 

You will be received in First Aid and Reception Centres (CPSA - Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza) facilities established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual migrant.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance.

 

Important!

Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times. 

STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

 

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact Red Cross. 

  • For families arriving on the same boat, naval forces, providing support in the sea, are looking not to separate family members.
  • If families arrived separately and are in different facilities, each facility is responsible for requesting permission from the Prefecture to unify family members in one facility. 

In every Prefecture there is immigration office, where every foreigner who is in the territory of Italy holding a residence permit valid for not less than one year, can ask permission for family reunification. 

If you have been separated from a family member, you can call telephone number: 09 22 483 542. 

You may also contact the Red Cross in other European countries:

content.title: LODGING
content.section:
Lodging is provided in Sicily. 

CPSA in Lampedusa is in district of Imbriacola and can accommodate up to 500 people.

Upon arrival, you will be accomodated in CPSA (Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza), established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual person.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance. 

CPSA in Lampedusa can accommodate up to 500 people.

CPSA in Pozzallo can accomodate up to 300 people. 

CPSA in Porto Empedokle can accomodate up to 300 people. 

CPSA in Trapani can accomodate up to 400 people. 

CPSA in Augusta can accomodate up to 300 people.

content.title: REGISTRATION
content.section:
Registration process is conducted in CPSA HotSpot.

The operational support provided under the Hotspot approach will concentrate on:

  • registration,
  • identification,
  • fingerprinting and
  • debriefing of asylum seekers,
  • as well as return operations.

In Italy, the regional headquarters in Catania (Sicily) is coordinating the work in four ports which have been identified as Hotspots: 

Pozzallo, Porto Empedocle and Trapani in Sicily and Lampedusa.

In each of these Hotspots, first reception facilities are in place with a capacity for receiving approximately 1 500 persons for the purpose of identification, registration and fingerprinting.

content.title: SERVICES
content.section:
The following services are available in Lampedusa, provided by specialized organizations. 

Italian Red Cross CRI (Croce Rossa Italiana) is always present to those disembarking from the sea, with doctors, paramedics and cultural mediators. CRI also has carried out a project “Safe point” for health / humanitarian assistance to the migrant people in transit (Region Sicilia).

EMERGENCY - Assistance is provided to foreigners disembarking in Augusta, Catania, and Messina. There is a mobile clinic HotSpot in Pozzalo and a reception center in Augusta and Agrigento.

MSF – provide assistance to foreigners disembarking in Trapani and have mobile psychological support ambulance in Trapani. 

TERRE DES HOMMES – provide psychological assistance to unaccompanied minors on their own in Siracusa and Pozzallo.

SAVE THE CHILDREN is providing assistance to unaccompanied minors in all ports where foreigners are disembarking.

content.title: INTERNATIONAL PROTECTION IN SLOVENIA
content.section:
From the Republic of Slovenia’s Ministry of the Interior website:

The Republic of Slovenia provides international protection and asylum and allows for accommodation in an integration house, financial compensation for private accommodation and a passport for a refugee upon recognized international protection status.

The purpose of international protection is to provide protection to those individuals to whom protection is not provided by their countries of citizenship or permanent residence (countries of origin). Those countries cannot or are not willing to implement laws or do not adhere to the international conventions they signed.

content.title: WHO CAN APPLY?
content.section:
• Any foreigner or person without citizenship who thinks that he or she is systematically persecuted in their home country due to his or her political belief or due to his or her religion, race, nationality or ethnic origin may ask for international protection and asylum.
  • Anyone who thinks that his or her life or freedom would be endangered or he or she could be exposed to torture or inhuman treatment or punishment upon returning to his or her home country may also ask for international protection. The competent body, the Status Affairs Division of the Ministry of the Interior, decides on the application.
  • The intention of filing an application for international protection can be communicated by the applicant at a police station or to a police officer, or at the asylum home of the International Protection Division. Such an intention can also be communicated to another state body; however, this body needs to refer the applicant to the International Protection Division of the Ministry of the Interior or to the asylum home. In any event, the formal receipt of an application for international protection in the presence of an appropriate translator or interpreter is performed at the asylum home, where the applicant will be accommodated after the receipt of the application.
  • The conditions for the granting of international protection are laid down by the International Protection Act.

content.title: WHO IS CONSIDERED A REFUGEE?
content.section:
Refugee status is recognized to a person that provides justifiable and authentic proof that he or she is endangered in his or her home country due to race, religion, nationality, political belief or affiliation to a special social group.

Subsidiary protection is granted to a person that does not meet conditions for the recognition of refugee status but provides justifiable and authentic reasons that serious damage would be caused to him or her upon return to the home country (death penalty or execution, torture or inhuman or degrading treatment). Subsidiary protection is also granted for serious and individual threats against life or freedom of the applicant due to indiscriminate violence in situations of international or internal armed conflict in the country of origin.

content.title: YOUR RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS
content.section:
• After the receipt of the application for international protection, the person is accommodated in the asylum home, where he or she has a right to food, clothing and footwear. The refugee is entitled to three meals a day. Upon accommodating the refugee in the appropriate department, he or she receives an accommodation package, which contains all necessary sanitary products and bedding.
  • After the interview with the applicant has been completed, he or she may get private accommodation after residing in the asylum home for a week. An inter-departmental expert commission decides on the application on private accommodation.
  • The Rules on the rights of applicants for international protection stipulate in more detail the rights and obligations of the applicants for international protection: 
    • right to reside in Slovenia;
    • right to follow the procedure in a language that the applicant understands;
    • right to information;
    • right to basic care if accommodated in an asylum home;
    • right to financial aid if accommodated in private accommodation;
    • right to free-of-charge legal aid in the procedure before an Administrative Court or Supreme Court until the final decision;
    • right to health care;
    • right to education;
    • right to work and employment;
    • right to humanitarian aid.
  • Applicants for international protection have the right to reside in Slovenian from the date of filing the application for international protection until the final decision on the application. This right enables the applicant to move freely throughout the entire territory of the Republic of Slovenia. Immediately after the filing of the application, an official issues an international protection applicant card, which serves as a temporary residence permit.
  • Counselors for refugees provide assistance in the procedure for the granting of international protection before an Administrative Court or Supreme Court until the final decision.
  • When a person is granted international protection, he or she is entitled to free-of-charge accommodation in an integration house for a period of one year after the granting of international protection status, i.e., recognized refugee status or subsidiary protection status.
  • When the applicant is guaranteed private accommodation and concludes a tenancy agreement, the Ministry of the Interior grants him or her financial compensation for private accommodation.
  • The amount of financial compensation for private accommodation depends on the number of family members who hold an international protection status and who exercise the right to financial compensation for private accommodation. Single persons with international protection are entitled to financial compensation for private accommodation in the amount of basic minimum income. If the contractual amount of rent and other costs arising from renting a dwelling is lower than the amount of the financial compensation for private accommodation to which the person with international protection is entitled, the financial compensation is reduced accordingly. Furthermore, the amount of financial compensation for a person with international protection who has his or her own income, or whose subsistence is ensured in another way, is reduced in relation to his or her income and the income of the family members, respectively.
  • Persons with recognized refugee status may file an application for the issue of a passport for refugees and need to enclose two photographs with the application. The passport is issued with a validity of ten years. 
  • Persons with granted subsidiary protection use their national passport. If a person does not have its national passport, the competent authority for the duration of subsidiary protection issues a passport for foreigners, unless there are grounds for refusal in accordance with the law governing the entry, exit and residence of foreigners in the Republic of Slovenia.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
If you are In Serbia, you have these options:

1.) ASYLUM

You can express intention to apply for asylum approaching the police at the border or inside the country.  

In Belgrade, you may put in a request by going to the Police Station Department for Foreigners (Uprava za strance):
Address: Savska 35
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3618 744
Operating hours: 08:00 - 22:00 daily

Starting the asylum procedure, you will be referred to and allowed to stay in an asylum center. There you will be provided with assistance (food, hygiene items, medical services, psycho-social help and legal assistance).  

Serbia is obliged to provide accommodation to refugees during the asylum procedure.

​DECLARING ASYLUM IN SERBIA    

2.) VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can ask for the assistance to be returned to your country of origin. For more information, contact the IOM office.

IOM’s main offices in Serbia are at:
Address: Skenderbegova 3, 11000 Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3282 075
Email: iombeograd@iom.int

There is no possibility for relocation to the European Union from Serbia.

You can ask for advice from the Belgrade Center for Human Rights, which provides free legal help.      

Address: Kneza Milosa 4, Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 308 5328
Mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508
Viber and WhatsApp through the mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508

They also offer videos on the asylum process in several languages here.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: BASIC INFORMATION
content.section:
You are on the island of Lampedusa, Italy. 

 

Vital Arrival Information:

You will be received in First Aid and Reception Centres (CPSA - Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza) facilities established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual migrant.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance.

CPSA in Lampedusa is in district of Imbriacola and can accommodate up to 500 people.

 

Important!

Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times. 

STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

 

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact Red Cross. 

  • For families arriving on the same boat, naval forces, providing support in the sea, are looking not to separate family members.
  • If families arrived separately and are in different facilities, each facility is responsible for requesting permission from the Prefecture to unify family members in one facility. If you are in Lampedusa, Prefecture in charge is Agrigento.

In every Prefecture there is immigration office, where every foreigner who is in the territory of Italy holding a residence permit valid for not less than one year, can ask permission for family reunification. 

If you have been separated from a family member, you can call telephone number: 09 22 483 542. 

You may also contact the Red Cross in other European countries:

content.title: REGISTRATION
content.section:
Registration process is conducted in CPSA HotSpot. 

The operational support provided under the Hotspot approach will concentrate on:

  • registration,
  • identification,
  • fingerprinting and
  • debriefing of asylum seekers,
  • as well as return operations.

In Italy, the regional headquarters in Catania (Sicily) is coordinating the work in four ports which have been identified as Hotspots: 

Pozzallo, Porto Empedocle and Trapani in Sicily and Lampedusa.

In each of these Hotspots, first reception facilities are in place with a capacity for receiving approximately 1 500 persons for the purpose of identification, registration and fingerprinting.

content.title: LODGING
content.section:
Lodging is provided in Lampedusa. CPSA in Lampedusa is in district of Imbriacola and can accommodate up to 500 people.

Upon arrival, you will be accomodated in CPSA (Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza), established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual person.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance.

content.title: SERVICES
content.section:
The following services are available in Lampedusa, provided by specialized organizations. 

Italian Red Cross CRI (Croce Rossa Italiana) is always present to those disembarking from the sea, with doctors, paramedics and cultural mediators. CRI also has carried out a project “Safe point” for health / humanitarian assistance to the migrant people in transit (Region Sicilia).

EMERGENCY - Assistance is provided to foreigners disembarking in Augusta, Catania, and Messina. There is a mobile clinic HotSpot in Pozzalo and a reception center in Augusta and Agrigento.

MSF – provide assistance to foreigners disembarking in Trapani and have mobile psychological support ambulance in Trapani. 

TERRE DES HOMMES – provide psychological assistance to unaccompanied minors on their own in Siracusa and Pozzallo.

SAVE THE CHILDREN is providing assistance to unaccompanied minors in all ports where foreigners are disembarking.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.

    • age

content.title: BASIC INFORMATION
content.section:
You are in Pozzallo, Sicily, Italy. 

 

Vital Arrival Information:

You will be received in First Aid and Reception Centres (CPSA - Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza) facilities established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual migrant.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance.

CPSA in Pozzalo is in province of Ragusa. It can accommodate up to 300 people.

 

Important!

Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times. 

STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

 

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact Red Cross. 

  • For families arriving on the same boat, naval forces, providing support in the sea, are looking not to separate family members.
  • If families arrived separately and are in different facilities, each facility is responsible for requesting permission from the Prefecture to unify family members in one facility. If you are in Pozzallo, Prefecture in charge is Ragusa.

In every Prefecture there is immigration office, where every foreigner who is in the territory of Italy holding a residence permit valid for not less than one year, can ask permission for family reunification. 

If you have been separated from a family member, you can call telephone number: 09 22 483 542.

content.title: REGISTRATION
content.section:
Registration process is conducted in CPSA HotSpot.

The operational support provided under the Hotspot approach will concentrate on:

  • registration,
  • identification,
  • fingerprinting and
  • debriefing of asylum seekers,
  • as well as return operations.

In Italy, the regional headquarters in Catania (Sicily) is coordinating the work in four ports which have been identified as Hotspots: 

Pozzallo, Porto Empedocle and Trapani in Sicily and Lampedusa.

In each of these Hotspots, first reception facilities are in place with a capacity for receiving approximately 1 500 persons for the purpose of identification, registration and fingerprinting.

content.title: LODGING
content.section:
Lodging is provided in Pozzallo. CPSA in Pozzallo can accommodate up to 300 people.

Upon arrival, you will be accomodated in CPSA (Centro primo soccorso e accoglienza), established in 2006 in order to provide immediate assistance to the foreigners who just arrived to Italy. After that, you will be transferred to other centers in Italy (CDA o CARA o CIE, CAS, SPRAR). Transfers are conducted according to legal situation of each individual person.

You should be held here less than 72 hours, which is the necessary time to accomplish assistance.

content.title: SERVICES
content.section:
The following services are available in Lampedusa, provided by specialized organizations. 

Italian Red Cross CRI (Croce Rossa Italiana) is always present to those disembarking from the sea, with doctors, paramedics and cultural mediators. CRI also has carried out a project “Safe point” for health / humanitarian assistance to the migrant people in transit (Region Sicilia).

EMERGENCY - Assistance is provided to foreigners disembarking in Augusta, Catania, and Messina. There is a mobile clinic HotSpot in Pozzalo and a reception center in Augusta and Agrigento.

MSF – provide assistance to foreigners disembarking in Trapani and have mobile psychological support ambulance in Trapani. 

TERRE DES HOMMES – provide psychological assistance to unaccompanied minors on their own in Siracusa and Pozzallo.

SAVE THE CHILDREN is providing assistance to unaccompanied minors in all ports where foreigners are disembarking.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
If you are In Serbia, you have these options:

1.) ASYLUM

You can express intention to apply for asylum approaching the police at the border or inside the country.  

In Belgrade, you may put in a request by going to the Police Station Department for Foreigners (Uprava za strance):
Address: Savska 35
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3618 744
Operating hours: 08:00 - 22:00 daily

Starting the asylum procedure, you will be referred to and allowed to stay in an asylum center. There you will be provided with assistance (food, hygiene items, medical services, psycho-social help and legal assistance).  

Serbia is obliged to provide accommodation to refugees during the asylum procedure.

​DECLARING ASYLUM IN SERBIA    

2.) VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can ask for the assistance to be returned to your country of origin. For more information, contact the IOM office.

IOM’s main offices in Serbia are at:
Address: Skenderbegova 3, 11000 Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3282 075
Email: iombeograd@iom.int

There is no possibility for relocation to the European Union from Serbia.

You can ask for advice from the Belgrade Center for Human Rights, which provides free legal help.      

Address: Kneza Milosa 4, Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 308 5328
Mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508
Viber and WhatsApp through the mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508

They also offer videos on the asylum process in several languages here.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: +30 210 6988 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION

If you are In Serbia, you have these options:

1.) ASYLUM

You can express intention to apply for asylum approaching the police at the border or inside the country.  

In Belgrade, you may put in a request by going to the Police Station Department for Foreigners (Uprava za strance):
Address: Savska 35
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3618 744
Operating hours: 08:00 - 22:00 daily

  • Starting the asylum procedure, you will be referred to and allowed to stay in an asylum center. There you will be provided with assistance (food, hygiene items, medical services, psycho-social help and legal assistance).  
  • Serbia is obliged to provide accommodation to refugees during the asylum procedure.

​DECLARING ASYLUM IN SERBIA    

2.) VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can ask for the assistance to be returned to your country of origin. For more information, contact the IOM office.

IOM’s main offices in Serbia are at:
Address: Skenderbegova 3, 11000 Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 3282 075
Email: iombeograd@iom.int

There is no possibility for relocation to the European Union from Serbia.

You can ask for advice from the Belgrade Center for Human Rights, which provides free legal help.      

Address: Kneza Milosa 4, Belgrade
Tel: + 381 (0) 11 308 5328
Mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508
Viber and WhatsApp through the mobile tel: + 381 (0) 64 8246 508

They also offer videos on the asylum process in several languages here.

content.title: TRANSPORTATION TO BELGRADE
content.section:
​Bus:

  • Belgrade: If you wish to go to Belgrade, you may take a bus. Belgrade is approximately 335 km away, and buses to Belgrade take about 4-5 hours.   
  • Buses leave from the central square, Trg Dr Zorana Djindjica 4, and cost roughly €15. They depart at: 03:00, 05:20, 12:00, 17:00 daily.  


Train:

  • There is a train that leaves from the main train station at the far end of town. Trains depart every day at 12:40 and 21:10, and cost approximately €9.20. The train will take you to Belgrade, which takes roughly 7-8 hours. 


Taxi:

  • There are also taxis that can take you to Belgrade. These are very expensive. Taxis to Belgrade cost around €200 per trip (not per person). If you do take a taxi, it is recommended that you agree on the price before getting in.

content.title: LOCAL TRANSPORTATION
content.section:
• The center of the town of Dimitrovgrad (where you can find shops, restaurants, pharmacies etc.) is close to the border Police Station. There is essentially one main street, called Balkanska with (pharmacies, a train station etc.).
  • You can get there by walking about for 10 minutes, or you can take a taxi which should cost no more than €1. Taxis line up outside of the gate of the Registration Centre.

  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: + 30 210 69 88 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For information on declaring asylum in Greece, contact a UNHCR representative in your location or go to the Government of Greece’s website.
  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.
  • If you have family members and close relatives in an EU country, that will be taken into account in your application. However, it does not guarantee that you will be placed in that country.
  • To process your application, you must leave a phone number where you can be contacted. If your phone number changes, you must call the EASO Information Number below to notify them of your new phone number.

For more information, you can also contact the European Asylum Support Office Information:

Athens Office:
Tel: + 30 694 482 9138
cos.athens@easo.europa.eu
Operating Hours: 09:00-17:00 (Monday-Friday).

HOW TO APPLY FOR VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can voluntarily ask to be returned to your country of origin through the International Organization for Migration (IOM). For more information about voluntary return, check with IOM officers at your location or in Athens.

International Organization for Migration (IOM)
Tel: + 30 210 99 19 040
Address: Dodekanisou 6, 17456, Alimos, Athens
Metro: Red line (close to Ilioupoli station)
Operating hours: 08:30 - 16:00

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.

  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: LODGING
content.section:
Large tents and housing units are available in Diavata. To access accomodation, you will need to be registered and provide your name, nationality, date of birth and gender.

Please note that Diavata is an open camp. This means you may come and go as you please.

content.title: SERVICES
content.section:
The following services are available at Diavata: 

  • Medical services and referrals in case of emergency (24/7)
  • Food
  • Hot showers
  • Toilets and a handwashing area 
  • Hygiene product distribution 
  • Free wifi
  • Children`s space
  • Woman`s space 
  • Phone charging facilities
  • Blanket and clothing distributions (based on need and availability) 
  • Baby program: food and creams (for children 6 month to 2 years) 
  • Classes for children (Greek language, English language)
  • Classes for adults (Greek language)
  • Daily excursion to Thessaloniki every Wednesday at 10:00  

WARNING: The climate in Europe can be very cold. If you have warm clothing for yourself and your families, please make sure to keep them with you.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.
