content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: + 30 210 69 88 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For information on declaring asylum in Greece, contact a UNHCR representative in your location or go to the Government of Greece’s website.
  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.
  • If you have family members and close relatives in an EU country, that will be taken into account in your application. However, it does not guarantee that you will be placed in that country.
  • To process your application, you must leave a phone number where you can be contacted. If your phone number changes, you must call the EASO Information Number below to notify them of your new phone number.

For more information, you can also contact the European Asylum Support Office Information:

Athens Office:
Tel: + 30 694 482 9138
cos.athens@easo.europa.eu
Operating Hours: Monday-Friday, 09:00-17:00
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can voluntarily ask to be returned to your country of origin through the International Organization for Migration (IOM). For more information about voluntary return, check with IOM officers at your location or in Athens.

International Organization for Migration (IOM)
Tel: + 30 210 99 19 040
Address: Dodekanisou 6, 17456, Alimos, Athens
Metro: Red line (close to Ilioupoli station)
Operating hours: 08:30 - 16:00

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.

  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: +30 210 6988 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For information on declaring asylum in Greece, contact a UNHCR representative in your location or go to the Government of Greece’s website.
  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.
  • If you have family members and close relatives in an EU country, that will be taken into account in your application. However, it does not guarantee that you will be placed in that country.
  • To process your application, you must leave a phone number where you can be contacted. If your phone number changes, you must call the EASO Information Number below to notify them of your new phone number.

For more information, you can also contact the European Asylum Support Office Information:

Operating Hours: Monday-Friday, 09:00-17:00

You can voluntarily ask to be returned to your country of origin through the International Organization for Migration (IOM). For more information about voluntary return, check with IOM officers at your location or in Athens.

  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: BASIC INFORMATION
content.section:
You are on the island of Chios, Greece.

Important!

  • If you enter Greece irregularly from the 20th of March onwards, you are subject to the new EU - Turkey agreement. You will be held in a Closed Type Facility (VIAL) until your case is decided upon. You have the right to appeal the decision of your detention as well as any eventual decision of removal.
  • You have the right to apply for International Protection. If you wish to apply for asylum in Greece you should make this clear to the Police when they register you. Please see below for more details. 
  • Ask the authorities for information on your legal rights. You may also request the assistance of a lawyer. 
  • You may also be eligible for family reunification or voluntary return. Please see below for more details.
  • Only if you express your wish to apply for asylum or family reunification to the Police will your claim be referred to the Greek Asylum Service. They will then register you and give you an appointment for an individual interview.
  • If you are alone and you are under 18 please inform the Police.
  • If you avoid registration here, you RISK being arrested elsewhere in Greece as an undocumented person. The northern borders are closed. Do not expose yourself to illegal networks or smugglers by attempting to cross them. The physical security of yourself and your family may be put in danger.
  • STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.
  • Tap water on Chios is NOT safe to drink. Please drink only mineral water on Chios. It is appropriate for washing, however.          
  • The Red Cross has a free and confidential information hotline in Arabic, Farsi and 9 other languages which you may also call at + 30 210 514 0440. It is open from 08:00-20:00 Monday-Friday.

There are a number of ways you can keep yourself or your families safe. Please see below for more information on tips to keep yourselves safe.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
You are on the Greek island of Samos.

Important!

  • If you enter Greece irregularly from the 20th of March onwards, you are subject to the new EU - Turkey agreement. You will be held in the Hotspot, a Closed Type Facility, until your case is decided upon. You have the right to appeal the decision of your detention as well as any eventual decision of removal. Ask the UNHCR for information on your legal rights (please see below for more information). You may also request the assistance of a lawyer.
  • You have the right to apply for International Protection. If you wish to apply for asylum in Greece you should make this clear to the Police when they register you.
  • You may also be eligible for family reunification or voluntary return. Please see below for more details.
  • Only if you express your wish to apply for asylum or family reunification to the Police will your claim be referred to the Greek Asylum Service. They will then register you and give you an appointment for an individual interview.
  • If you are alone and you are under 18 please inform the Police.
  • If you avoid registration here, you RISK being arrested elsewhere in Greece as an undocumented person. The northern borders are closed. Do not expose yourself to illegal networks or smugglers by attempting to cross them. The physical security of yourself and your family may be put in danger.
  • STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.
  • Tap water on Samos is generally safe to drink. 
  • The Red Cross has a free and confidential information hotline in Arabic, Farsi and 9 other languages which you may also call at + 30 210 514 0440. It is open from 08:00-20:00 Monday-Friday.

There are a number of ways you can keep yourself or your families safe. Please see below for more information on tips to keep yourselves safe.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: + 30 210 69 88 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For information on declaring asylum in Greece, contact a UNHCR representative in your location or go to the Government of Greece’s website.
  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.
  • If you have family members and close relatives in an EU country, that will be taken into account in your application. However, it does not guarantee that you will be placed in that country.
  • To process your application, you must leave a phone number where you can be contacted. If your phone number changes, you must call the EASO Information Number below to notify them of your new phone number.

For more information, you can also contact the European Asylum Support Office Information:

content.title: VOLUNTARY RETURN
content.section:
For those who are eligible, IOM undertakes the registration of those who wish to return to their country of origin, the issuance of travel documents and tickets, the provision of a reinstallation grant before departure from Greece, the escorting to the airport and the reception in the transit and final destination countries. IOM staff and interpreters work to provide information on the procedure so that people may make an informed decision about voluntary return prior to registering for it. 

Eligibility depends upon your country of origin. You must have an identity document (either an original or a copy) in order to be registered for voluntary return. Before departure to your country of origin, at the airport, a reinstallation sum of 400€ will be given to you to cover your initial expenses. 

Reintegration assistance in the country of origin is also a service that can be provided based on specific selection criteria.

If you are interested in voluntary return, please contact IOM in the Samos Hotspot.

content.title: VITAL ARRIVAL INFO
content.section:
You are on the island of Leros, Greece.


VITAL ARRIVAL INFORMATION:

In general, different regulations apply to people who arrived before March 20, 2016 and to those who arrived to the Greek islands on or after March 20, 2016. Your movement will depend upon the authorities' decision and the Greek documents you were given.

  • Those who arrived before March 20 and were given valid police documents permitting movement are allowed to circulate freely around Leros and/or Greece. Please check your police note carefully to understand your rights and any restrictions on movement.
  • Those who arrived on or after March 20 will be held at Lepida reception center for processing and are generally not permitted to move around freely. It is highly likely you will remain in this closed facility until your case is decided upon. This procedure will take some time, so please be patient.
    The Greek authorities can legally detain you for the purposes of registration and identification for 25 days. 

These are some of your important rights:

  • You have the right to seek asylum in Greece. You can express this will to the police during registration or any other representative of the Greek authorities who has the duty to transfer your claim to the Asylum Office.
  • ​When you express your desire to seek asylum in Greece, the Asylum Office will inform you on the procedure relating to this, your legal rights, and, when the process is finalized, the outcome of your claim for asylum.
  • If you have a member of your nuclear family (husband/wife, children under 18 years) legally residing in an EU member state, you may be eligible for family reunification. Please declare this to the Asylum Office or the Greek Authorities.
  • If you are an unaccompanied minor child (under 18 years old without parents or documented legal guardian) and your parents, siblings, or other close relatives (uncles/aunts, grandparents) are legally residing in an EU member state, you may be eligible for family reunification. Please declare this to the Asylum Office or the Greek Authorities.
  • See below for general information on asylum.

Important!

  • Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times.
  • STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact the Red Cross or UNHCR on Leros.

  • You may also call the Tracing Service of the Hellenic Red Cross: +30 210 5230043
    Hours: 08:00-14:30 Monday-Friday.
    • It is never too late to report a missing person – even years after you were separated. You will get a unique number for your case that you may use anywhere the world. Please leave a permanent way for the Red Cross to reach you.

content.section:
Where you may be lodged depends upon your arrival date to Leros and other specific considerations: 

If you arrived on or after March 20, 2016 you will be placed in Lepida, which is a closed reception center. This means you are not permitted to leave, until you have proper documentation.

In some cases, you may be lodged by authorities in the PIKPA shelter based on their criteria and decision. PIKPA is located on the grounds of a hospital near the reception centre. It is organized by the Greek government.  

People who are permitted to move freely around Leros can choose private accommodation. There are hotels on the island available for a cost.

HOTELS

€15/adult (minimum 2 people per room). Children are free.

Tel: 22470 22469

content.section:
In many cases, you will only be allowed to move freely on the island of Leros. 

The centre of the city (Lakki) is approximately a 45-minute walk from the reception centre. Here is a map of Lakki.
However, if you need to go elsewhere, there is bus service and taxis.

Bus service

The bus costs €1, and stops about every kilometer (Agira, Panteli, Platanos, Ayia Marina, etc.)

There are two main bus stations:

  1. one block north of the taxi stand in downtown Lakki
  2. outside the airport at Patheni

Taxi service

There are two main taxi stands:

  1. by the marina in Lakki
  2. in Platanos

It is a €6 euro trip from Lakki to Platanos and €12 euros from Lakki to the airport. (Unless you are going to the airport, a ride should not cost more than €6.)

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
  • Be careful around bodies of water. Make sure children do not fall in.
  • Large crowds can be unpredictable. If groups become violent, it is important to remove yourself and your family temporarily until the context calms down.
  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: KOS: VITAL ARRIVAL INFO
content.section:
You are on the island of Kos in Greece. 


VITAL ARRIVAL INFORMATION:

In general, different regulations apply to people who arrived before March 20, 2016 and to those who arrived to the Greek islands on or after March 20, 2016. Your movement will depend upon the authorities' decision and the Greek documents you were given.

  • Those who arrived before March 20 and were given valid police documents permitting movement are either allowed to circulate freely around Kos and/or Greece. Please check your police note carefully to understand your rights and any restrictions on movement.
  • Those who arrived on or after March 20 will be held at Kos reception center for processing and are generally not permitted to move around freely. It is highly likely you will remain in this closed facility until your case is decided upon. This procedure will take some time, so please be patient.
    The Greek authorities can legally detain you for the purposes of registration and identification for 25 days. 

These are some of your important rights:

  • You have the right to seek asylum in Greece. You can express this will to the police during registration or any other representative of the Greek authorities who has the duty to transfer your claim to the Asylum Office.
  • ​When you express your desire to seek asylum in Greece, the Asylum Office will inform you on the procedure relating to this, your legal rights, and, when the process is finalized, the outcome of your claim for asylum.
  • If you have a member of your nuclear family (husband/wife, children under 18 years) legally residing in an EU member state, you may be eligible for family reunification. Please declare this to the Asylum Office or the Greek Authorities.
  • If you are an unaccompanied minor child (under 18 years old without parents or documented legal guardian) and your parents, siblings, or other close relatives (uncles/aunts, grandparents) are legally residing in an EU member state, you may be eligible for family reunification. Please declare this to the Asylum Office or the Greek Authorities.
  • See below for general information on asylum.

Important!

  • Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times.
  • STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact the Red Cross where you are.

  • You may also call the Tracing Service of the Hellenic Red Cross: +30 210 5230043
    Hours: 08:00-14:30 Monday-Friday.
    • It is never too late to report a missing person – even years after you were separated. You will get a unique number for your case that you may use anywhere the world. Please leave a permanent way for the Red Cross to reach you.

You may also contact the Red Cross in other European countries.

Austria +43 15 890 0126
Croatia +385 14 655 814

Greece +30 210 524 2194

The Red Cross has a free and confidential information hotline in Arabic and Farsi (and 9 other languages) which you may also call at +30 210 514 0440. It is open from 08:00-20:00 Monday-Friday.
 

There are a number of ways you can keep yourself or your families safe. Please see below for more information on tips to keep yourselves safe.

content.title: ASYLUM INFORMATION
content.section:
! A new European Union – Turkey agreement has changed your options.

If you arrived in Greece on or after March 20, 2016 you have the right to:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Opt for voluntary return to your country of origin.

    If you do not choose one of these options, you may be sent back to Turkey.


If you arrived in Greece before March 20, 2016 you can:

  • Apply for asylum in Greece.
  • Apply to be reunited with a close family member who is legally residing in another European country. This process is linked to your asylum application. You must express your desire for family reunification when you apply for asylum.
  • Apply for relocation to other EU member states (depending upon your nationality, please check with EASO).
  • Opt for a voluntary return to your country of origin.

If you do not wish to apply for asylum in Greece or your asylum request has been rejected (in this case, you may appeal this decision to a second instance committee in a court of law), you may be returned to your country of origin or a third country.

Asylum Help Line with recorded information for asylum seekers in 10 languages: +30 210 6988 660.

Please note that the processes for Asylum and Relocation are separate and distinct processes. Applying for one may impact your application for the other.
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR ASYLUM

  • For information on declaring asylum in Greece, contact a UNHCR representative in your location or go to the Government of Greece’s website.
  • For Arabic information, click here. For information in Farsi, click here, and in Dari, click here.
  • Currently, appointments for lodging international protection applications will be booked through Skype calls.
  • For the Skype schedule, please click here.
     

HOW TO APPLY FOR RELOCATION

Some people who arrived prior to March 20, 2016 may be eligible for relocation. Not all nationalities are eligible. For more information about the relocation program and to see if you qualify, contact UNHCR or European Asylum Support Office (EASO) officers at your location and notify them that you are interested in relocation.

  • You cannot choose where you will be relocated.
  • If you have family members and close relatives in an EU country, that will be taken into account in your application. However, it does not guarantee that you will be placed in that country.
  • To process your application, you must leave a phone number where you can be contacted. If your phone number changes, you must call the EASO Information Number below to notify them of your new phone number.

For more information, you can also contact the European Asylum Support Office Information:

Athens Office:
Tel: (+30) 694 482 9138
cos.athens@easo.europa.eu
Operating Hours: Monday-Friday, 09:00-17:00
 

HOW TO APPLY FOR VOLUNTARY RETURN

You can voluntarily ask to be returned to your country of origin through the International Organization for Migration (IOM). For more information about voluntary return, check with IOM officers at your location or in Athens.

International Organization for Migration (IOM)
Tel: (+30) 210 99 19 040
Address: Dodekanisou 6, 17456, Alimos, Athens
Metro: Red line, (close to Ilioupoli station)
Operating hours: 08:30 - 16:00

content.title: LODGING
content.section:
Where you may be lodged depends upon your arrival date to Kos and other specific considerations:

If you arrived on or after March 20, 2016 you may be detained by authorities or placed in a closed reception centre until your case is decided upon. This means you are not permitted to leave, until you have proper documentation.

Children on their own may be placed in special shelters run by NGOs.
 

Refugees are permitted to stay in hotels in Kos with proof of registration/police note. Availability may be limited.

  • If someone is using violence against you or one of your family members (or is threatening to do so), inform authorities or aid organizations. They can help protect you.
  • If you encounter a child who is alone, inform the authorities or aid organizations so that they can help you.

Staying healthy:

  • Allow your children time to rest, play and sleep.
  • Ensure that the children eat enough when food is available.
  • If your child becomes ill, continue to encourage him/her to drink and eat, and seek help from a medical center or aid organization.

Feeding Babies:

  • If you are breastfeeding your baby, do not stop breastfeeding. This is the most reliable, cheapest, and safest way of feeding and protecting your baby.
  • Do not start to use infant formula if you have never used it, it is very difficult to prepare in this situation and your baby is more likely to become sick with diarrhea and other infections.
  • If you have a baby over six months of age, continue to breastfeed as often and as long as possible, in addition to adding other foods. You do not need to use infant formula but can use other milk sources instead.
  • If you wish to continue to use feeding bottle for your baby, hygienic preparation with boiled water is strongly recommended to reduce the risk of contamination.

content.title: TIPS FOR CHILDREN ON THEIR OWN
content.section:
Here are some tips for how to stay safe:

  • If you have contact with your family, continue to update them about your location.
  • Avoid sleeping outside at night. 
  • Avoid moving around alone; it is better to be in a group.
  • Keep a list of important telephone numbers (for example, your family) with you. Memorize the most important ones.
  • If an individual (who is not wearing an ID card or a uniform from an aid organization) is offering you a job, transportation or shelter, be careful. Their intentions might not be good. Do not go with them by yourself. You can always ask people for their names and what organizations they work for. 
  • Avoid staying in a private house by yourself. Especially when no one knows that you are there.
  • If someone is using violence against you or is threatening to do so, report this to the authorities or to an aid organisation immediately; they can support you.
  • If the police want to detain you, ask if you can speak to a social worker or a person working for an aid organization. Ask them to inform your family.
  • Try to eat enough when you have access to food or when food is available.
  • Seek medical attention if you need it.

content.title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION
content.section:
Safety Tips: Protecting Yourself and Others

  • Be aware of strangers and people offering to take care of you or your children – you may be at risk of being hurt, exploited, or trafficked.
  • Be aware of smugglers or strangers offering jobs, travel or accommodation where you must “pay them back”.
  • As a refugee you are in danger of being taken advantage of. Smugglers are known to prey on people in your situation. They can trap people into forced labor and sexual exploitation through deception, threats and violence.
  • Be aware of anyone who wants to take your passport or documents.
  • Be aware of opportunities that sound too good to be true.
  • Be aware of the risks of moving around at night. Avoid unlit areas and ask an adult you trust to accompany you to the latrines.
  • Keep all important documents and forms of identification in your possession at all times.
  • Write on a piece of paper important phone numbers, including the number of someone you feel safe contacting if you are in trouble.
  • Women who are alone - avoid being isolated or staying with strangers. Find someone you trust and stay together.
  • Relief assistance should be given without conditions. You do not have to provide sex, money or other favors in order to get help.
  • You have the right to complain and to report any exploitation or abuse by humanitarian workers, volunteers, authorities or those providing assistance.
  • If anyone (a stranger or a member of your family) hurts you, scares you, makes you feel bad or touches you in way you don’t like:
    • TELL someone you trust. Look for a representative from UNHCR or other humanitarian organizations. ASK them for any help you need.
    • You may also call the police.

content.title: TIPS FOR KEEPING FAMILIES SAFE
content.section:
• Keep your family together.
  • Identify meeting points in case you get separated.
  • Make sure children know: 
    • their full name
    • name of their parents, brothers and sisters
    • age
    • where they come from
    • whom they are with
    • and contact information.
  • Write this on a piece of paper and keep it in the children’s pocket in case the child gets separated from the group. 
  • Have important contact numbers written down on separate papers for each individual member of the family.
  • Do not allow your children to be taken out of your sight by someone you do not know. Be aware of people offering you or your child money, a job, or somewhere to sleep - they may have bad intentions.
  • Talk with your children about potential risks and encourage them to report to you anything that worries them.
  • If someone wants to take photos of you or your family, you have the right to say no. Do not let people take your photo if you do not want them to.

 

  • Take time to rest, wash and relax.
  • If your children want to play or need support, see if there is a child-friendly space available. There may also be designated areas for children who have been separated from their families.
  • Be careful with open fires. Keep children at a safe distance from flames.
